reviews.review_text: This game is great in many, heavy aspects, and falls short on a few light ones. The negative aspects of it are more a matter of taste rather than being poor game design. Since so many negative reviews are written by people who think the game's too slow, I'll give a fast review so that you'll have time to play it sooner.  Pros: - Great game design. - Beautifully crafted world with a competent graphics engine. - Great soundtrack. - Combat is highly tactical and multifaceted. Planning and having a variety of strategies matter. (I recommend playing on Tactician Mode) - Profound character creation, that actually matters in gameplay.  - Dialogue choices (sometimes) matter and help build character traits. - Humour and pop-culture references. - Lots of secrets.  Matters of taste: - Very unforgiving to: Inexperienced RPG-players. Unskilled tacticians. People with bad dice rolls. Those who can't properly use Google as a last life-line. People who bought a keyboard without the F5 and F9 buttons. Sufferers of amnesia. - Slow, sometimes painfully slow. A beverage or friend to accompany you through some parts of the game is highly recommended.  - A bit too few 'in combat' tracks. - Arhu is ♥♥♥♥ing everywhere.  Cons: - Repetitive character auto-reactions to world effects. ('Feeling a bit hot under the collar!' 'On the mend!' 'What a deluge!' etcetera)  - Unnecessarily slow animations and queuing outside of combat. - A little too uninformative quest log. - Some quests/parts of quests are downright uninteresting. - As with any game of any publisher, a few bugs here and there.

I can not tell you properly with words how good this game is.  I will try however and I should start, as everyone, comparing it to old school RPG titles. Unlike recent RPG-called titles from this century —mostly made for the new generations of players, with little or no brains needed at all to solve quests—, Divinity: Original Sin looks like a true role playing game reminiscent of the old ages but with very cool new ideas —some of them unique— and fresh graphics.  The main characteristic, typical of Larian games, is the freedom to do almost everything you want: the game is classless, so you can choose a warrior in the beginning and later on you can change your mind and provide him with some spells or range skills, if you like it, when he level up; this way you will end up with four characters, two of them from the start and two more later on, with a combination of skills, traits and talents that fits you. You can interact with almost every item in the game: doors, chests, barrels, pictures, chairs, etc, and you can open them to look inside or destroy them if you prefer, or even take them and move them from one place to another. You can also choose if you prefer to talk to every NPC and solve quests, trade with them, or killing them if you like it, or even steal their items and loot their houses. Every action will make the villagers approach you in different ways, turning hostile to you or being polite instead. And if you don't like to trade with NPCs a lot you are able to craft your own gear and even spells if you choose to do it with the immense amount of ingredients and tools you will find everywhere.  What makes this game unique, and a gem, is a combination of the role playing part with the interaction between characters —even yours!— and its combat system. Divinity is not a combat focused game, it is more a conversational and exploration RPG title; however, combat is also very important and this is not a real time one, it is a turn-based combat system with action points mechanics that forces you to think about your resources, the enemies, and the environment; so each turn you can use your points to move, drink potions, attack or cast spells if you got enough points for them, or if you prefer you can reserve some of your remaining action points for your next turn, for example if you want to wait when the enemy is far away from you and later on you want to hit him two or three times in the same turn. The best part of the system is, no doubt, the chance —and mostly the need— of using the elements on your favour. It means you can cast a rain spell on your characters to stop them from burning; you can also cast rain on enemies, make them wet and then cast electricity spells for extra damage and stuns. You can also use ice spells if enemies are wet —state than come from your spells or from real rain itself!— to freeze them. You can shoot (after throwing it for example) an oil barrel with a fire spell to make it explode and damage the area, or just hit it with your arrows to make it pour the oil and later on cast fire on it if you wish. You can make an ice barrier to protect, wait until enemies are near it and then fire it, making it water and causing enemies to stumble, and then electrify them. You can combine elements to create clouds to avoid being a target. You can stealth and stab enemies too if you have the right character to do such a thing. You can use barrels and things of the environment to take cover, to protect you and to avoid damage. You can also try to flee if you find the situation too chaotic for your taste. You can... well, you can —and you should— do all these things if you want to survive, because combat is not always an easy task on this game.   For all these things I must say this is a heck of a game; I have not THAT fun with a videogame probably since some decades (I'm absolutely for real here). It's also true that there are some things that are not optimal and need improvement. Among the negatives, there is the camera movement, the slow pace of the game sometimes when you need to go from A to B, and the bad interfaz mechanics when you need to equip gear, change items from character to character, sell something or look at the items you got, or pick them. This is not a noob-friendly game; aside from the little dungeon tutorial at the start, you will find little or no help at all and you will find lost yourself if you are not used to RPGs games. However, asking in the forums will help you; there will be trolls, true, but overall the community will end up answering your questions and solving some of your starting problems, I'm pretty sure.  But if I take all these things together and put them all in a balance, I have to recommend this game to every player in the world. If you are an oldschool gamer you just can't pass on this. And if you are a new player and you didn't play or didn't even know any of the games other guys are mention, you have to give this one a chance and compare it yourself with the new RPGs. I promise you won't be disappointed.   PLUS you have also the Enhanced now, which add more quests, balanced skills, graphics, controller support, camera movement, subtitles in some languages, full voice actor and help with some of the issues the game got before. And even more difficult settings, with a new one with permadeath and only one savegame for massoquist tastes.

I have over 80 hours logged with the original version of this and it is by far one of my most favorite recent RPGS out there. They really added alot of changes. They revamped the crafting, added VO to practically ALL dialogue(and the voice acting is charming, IMO), and spruced up performance and made everything generally better.  If you played the original and loved it...this is complete fan service. Seriously. If all gaming studios treated their products with loving as Larian has done...the gaming industry would be unrecognizable.  I whole-heartedly recommend this. It makes a fantastic game even better.  ++voice acting; great quailty and I am damn sure the opening into narration is the same voice actress as the female british Inquisitor from DA:I ++dual wielding! ++GRENADES! ++more crafting/craftin UI overhaul! Hell...the entire UI has been changed and overhauled and for the better! ++optimized performance! ++better graphics all around than previous version. ++tactical mode for the people out there who love surprised and even greater challenge. They designed it to counter common strategies of players of the original. Seriously. I am seeing the AI do things I havent seen before in the original. Looks like its been upgradd. ++honour mode = one save only. Think of it as Ironman Mode. You die and your save is deleted.  I honestly cannot think of any cons right now. I will update this if I do. I am liking it that much.

By far the new standard in Couch Co-op games.  No longer is Player 2 invisibly bound to Player 1 by some kind of autoscrolling window game of running man simulator.  Quest, loot, fight, flee, craft, and create your own experinces independently, with a dynamic same/split screen interface.   Divide your party and combine again at any time through useful tools, like; Synced log/quest book, synced crafting recipies, magic pockets, send to player inventory, shared map/quest markers, and warp to player.   Use the character classes for Co-op role play, with skills like leadership for example granting bonus's to the characters when they are together.  The world of Rivellon is moulded by both of you, quest outcomes are debatable and roleplay dialogues allow you to express your opinion in game. Disagree with your flat-mate on whether or not those guards should be killed for treachery? Don't like how your girlfriends Cleric has decided to end a conflict peacefully? Oppose them in dialogue and force the issue to the fate of virtual rock, paper, scissors. Win and the desicion is made, lose and have comfort that your characters personality is still affected by your protest.   This game has recieved 9.0 /10 on IGN and 4.5/5 overall on Metacritic.  I persoanlly give it a 10/10 for co-op alone. Works great on steam link/controller.   Dont have a couch mate? the original sin comes with online co-op which plays out with the same flexibility.

I don't post much on Steam, and can't remember the last review I've written, but this game warrants one. Larian Studios has produced a masterpiece here. I love it. The co-op experience is amazing, and there are so many wonderful little quality components to this game, that I keep finding myself amazed! Just a few moments I loved:  1. The first time the buddy I am playing with interrupted my conversation and challenged the answer I gave the NPC, resulting in a rock/paper/scissors match. Very cool, and how these answers influence your tendencies, kudos!  2. The first battle I really experience environmental effects. Got frozen, then slipped on the ice, followed by 2 enemies falling beside me...  3. Learning how the crafting system actually works and then being floored by just how detailed it is. Holy crap, what a wonderful addition. Did my buddy really just break a bottle with a hammer and then put the shards of glass in an empty grenade to make an armor-piercing grenade. Cool!  4. When the enhanced edition came out and I got it for free. Thank you Larian Studios, love to see a studio that cares about the customer. Take note State of Decay. Additionally, what an improvement the enhanced edition actually is! Tactician mode is awesome.  I could go on, but I hope you get the point. If you enjoy computer RPGs, play this game. Even better if you can play with a buddy. Such an epic experience!

I know a lot of reviews say this game has no 'handholding' and is not for casual players, but don't let that neccessarily turn you away. I've never played one of those old-school CRPGs this game hearkens back to, so I entered the game pretty blind. It was very challenging at first, but once you get the hang of things and your characters have access to more tools and lower cooldowns, the combat aspect at least becomes much, much easier. And more fun. Every turn is like a puzzle. You don't just spam attacks (although I have two pure fighters who largely do... my two control mages support that.)   If you enjoy exploring every nook and cranny of a mysterious world, leaving no stone unturned, you will adore this game. While there is no quest tracker or markers or such modern amentities, the game actually does a good job of planting hints in the world (as well as updating your journal) so you're never left completely lost and confused. You get a great sense of satisfaction from figuring something out, putting the pieces together, following hints and clues, but nothing is completely obtuse. I've had to Google a couple times, but it's always been a 'DUH' moment. Never a 'how the hell would anyone ever figure that out' moment. Google isn't neccessary though... the answer is always in your inventory, in an NPC's dialogue, or hidden somewhere nearby!  I also like how I don't feel punished on normal difficulty for not building characters optimally. You have total freedom to build your characters as you choose, and it seems as long as you have a basic idea of what you want that character to do, you'll be fine. It seems like all the skill schools are pretty OP in their own ways. And you have a lot to play with when it comes to environmental effects, scrolls, grenades, etc. There's no battle you can't win, you just may have to try different approaches. There's a respec option available eventually, but I never thought, 'oh, I really ♥♥♥♥ed up and I NEED to respec.' I've been tempted to do it just because there are so many possibilities and things I want to try...  It's really difficult for me to feel compelled to finish a game these days, and I just can't get enough of this one. If you're a fan of RPGs of any sort and familiar with the basics, don't pass on this game. It's immersive, fun, rewarding, and best of all, you can play it with one hand. ;)

Engrossing RPG with many elements from older top-down, turn-based, games. Does not go easy on the player and the mechanics need to be discovered, but once they are you get a valid sense of achievement when you complete puzzles and defeat challenging bosses. Inventory is bit of a pain as nearly everything is craftable into something else, so you don't want to get rid of much and the interface doesn't give you a search option (just sort by, which can be helpful). I recommend long time TBRPG players to play the Tactician mode as it makes combat difficult (and sometimes frustrating), but it really makes you play the game. I've enjoyed many hours so far exploring, trying to work out crafting, completing as many quests as I can, and doing a lot of saving and reloading--especially the saving and reloading. ;)

Enhanced Edition with all the polish and improvements... it was great before, but the update put this over the top as one of the best turn based fantasy RPG's ever... if you enjoy fantasy rpg's... you need this game.

This crowdfunded RPG shouldn't be missed. Larian deserves a lot of praise for this. What stands out the most is how well designed, coded, and implemented the gameplay mechanics are. Lots of attention to detail here, and so much interactivity, such as the use of the elements (heat, water, air), being able to pick up and throw any reasonably sized object with ease, all of the different statuses. The UI is also good, although the hotbar should be expandable as it's annoying to have to cycle through them. This game has many different classes and a fairly complex leveling system, so that every character build will at least feel somewhat unique (although not quite as much as say the Neverwinter Nights games).  With all that being said, I can't help but feel this game is somewhat overrated by the press. It doesn't have the most role-playing in the world, and not even close. Yes, it has considerably more role-playing than the very limited Witcher franchise (they are based on novels after all), but compared to the all time greats it can be found lacking. Compared to Pillars of Eternity, it is also lacking in role-playing. There isn't much freedom in defining your characters' personalities, less than more recent BioWare games even. You are always a pair of Source Hunters out to save the world from evil, and there is only one dialogue 'skill' which is Charisma; however Charisma itself leads to three different dialogue options (each drawing from your Charisma score) which are Intimidate, Charm, and Reason. What you choose, and what you do throughout the game will alter the effective of these, putting points into traits such as Individualistic, Pragmatism, and more, but all these do is give you boosts to either Intimidate, Charm, or Reason, as well as a boost to certain other stats like Willpower (which is used only for resisting mind-affecting abilities).  At the end of the day, the dialogue is quite restrictive compared to games like Fallout, Fallout 2, Fallout: New Vegas, Neverwinter Nights 2, and Pillars of Eternity. Also, the game has two protagonists which you make at character creation, yet it lacks a party dialogue system found in games such as Neverwinter Nights 2: Storm of Zehir and Wasteland 2. This means, only one of your characters can be in a conversation and the other cannot freely intervene.  The quests are quite restricting compared to great RPGs. In order to beat this game I had to do things I didn't want to do, things that my character in my mind would not do. This game, despite the open level design, forces you down a specific path. Disappointing for an RPG.  Level design is very open. You are rarely limited in where you can go. However, enemies do not scale down to your level so many places will be utterly inaccessible just for this reason. Balance is a bit of an issue in this game, as generic human enemies of the same level have far more AP than you can ever have at that level, and wield weapons that are much higher level yet used with no penalty (and usually have more initiative too). In combat, enemies can open doors with no AP cost despite being nowhere near them. Then there are things such as one human enemy who is able to cast a master level spell with no cooldown. The imbalance is so obvious when (SPOILER ALERT) Bairdotr turns on you; one second she is part of your party, the next she levels up, has top tier equipment, and has far more AP than she should (unless her build changed to have most attribute points spent in Speed).   A shame, a mistake, and serious design flaws that don't affect smarter turn-based games. And then some enemies just have essentially no real weakness (not even talking about Source demons obviously since they do have a weakness and that's plot related). So there is some synthetic difficulty in this game, but not game breaking. A general balance issue is that archers are overpowered on both sides, enemy and player.  But many of these imbalances are somewhat offset by how stupid the AI is. The AI is nowhere near as smart as XCOM 2 and Enemy Unknown. Not that this is consolation mind you, this is just another flaw.   Furthermore, leveling up in this game is an extremely slow process. Far slower than any other RPG I've played. Too slow even, as it can slow down the pace a bit and it restricts the amount of combat abilities you get.   Speaking of combat abilities, I'd say there is less than Dragon Age: Origins and Pillars of Eternity. I'm used to Neverwinter Nights 2 so I'm spoiled and wish for more, but at least all of the abilities in this game are well designed and none seem useless. Some classes will have far more than others, naturally.  Writing and character development are not a focus of this game. Its tone is lighthearted, the real focus is on gameplay and exploration. Art design is pretty good, locations stand out a bit but nothing blows my mind and environments can seem more repetitive than some other games. The scale is large; locations are big and have a decent amount of detail and hidden places, but again nothing mind blowing.  Enhanced Edition contains many incremental improvements over the original, and they really add up. This game was crafted with a lot of care and programming skill. Now if only it had industry leading writers and directors. The second game has Chris Avellone on board, so I can't wait for that!

Just the fact that they gave this to existing owners of D:OS for free is enough to merit a 10/10 from me. With improved visuals, more gameplay, controller support, and fully voiced NPCs. this improves on an already amazing game in almost every aspect. Definitely one of my favorite RPGs I've played on Steam, if not number one. I cannot wait for D:OS 2! Just watched a video for the character creation and now they have races implemented and the graphics look insanely good! December 2016 can't get here fast enough.

I've played through this game twice so far, once when it came out and again in Enhanced Edition, both times in 100% co-op.  I have to say that the second playthrough was pretty fun. Knowing how to game the system, craft really powerful items and create a well balanced party that can smash through obstacles is pretty fun. The last boss just completely folded like a wet noodle in just over one turn of combat (it would've been less than a turn, but alas we cast some buffs that we didn't need). I had a particular amount of fun carrying a stack of oil and poison barrels in my characters inventory and throwing them out at bosses before/at the start of fights so that my ally could blow them up with meteors. KABOOM.   The 'Enhanced Edition' doesn't change much for most of the game, but does spruce up the ending quite a bit. And it's free anyhow, so what are you even complaining about? Unfortunately however, the game's approach to making puzzles is not enhanced. It's still 'go find this stupid switch that we hid between six levers' or whatever. Ugh. No thanks.   In any case, I'm quite looking forward to the sequel with it's competitive questing business. That will take a bit stronger storytelling than what they've been doing though. The story is already hard to follow with two people plugging along at different rates. I can't imagine how confusing it'd get when everyone's trying to kill each other or what have you.   But well, that's something for the future. For now, this is a good game that people should play.

Pros + Beautiful graphics + Open world which feels alive + Fully interactable environment + Interesting, nonlinear story + Ability to make decisions with different outcomes + Hilarious and clever narrative/dialogue + Challenging, rewarding combat + Lots of loot, items, and equipment to discover + Highly customizable character builds + High replayability  Cons - Some puzzles can be frustrating (for me, at least) - Limited character appearance options  Notes 1. Has the classic 'RPG' feel to it 2. Has online co-op 3. Does not hold your hand through quests, but has a useful journal to keep track of things  If you have any specific questions about the game, let me know!

I didn't realize it from the reviews, but this game is pretty much the closest you'll get to D&D: The Videogame while still having nice visuals and production value. It gives you so many options for everything because everything has interactions with everything else. You can light oil on fire, carry an entire loot-filled chest in your inventory until you can find lockpicks, spend hours talking to NPCs in town, or kill literally everyone you see. It's also one of the few turn-based games in which multiplayer is actually enjoyable. If you like having a lot of freedom, give this game a look.

D:OS is a classic isomorphic-style CRPG in the vein of Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and before that the 'gold box' games like Pool of Radiance and Curse of the Azure Bonds (For you older C64 gamers!!). The emphasis is on story, exploration, and complex turn-based combat.  Pros: > You can save at any time, including in the middle of combat > Compelling, complex narrative with many sub-plots and deep characters > Voice acting is excellent with only a few annoying performances > Beautifully rendered game world with the ability to zoom in close > No hand holding! You must often take your time and read objectives and notes carefully  > Exploring and fighting, the meat of the game, is an absolute blast. > Complex battles filled with elemental effects... like chess on a shifting, burning game board. > Role playing through dialog choices can reward you with relevant bonuses > Deep, complex crafting system > Very cool weapons, armor and items to find and equip.  > Interesting character upgrade system that seems to borrow the best parts of many different games. > Co-op support... although I did not make use of it.  Cons: > Some may find the lack of handholding frustrating... objectives are not always clear. > Bugs... game crashed hourly. > Crafting system seemed too complex to use without google help... although I was able to complete the game without using it much > Limited replayability. Although I like the idea of trying different builds, unlike Skyrim this is not an open world game and you must follow a prescribed path. > There are some game breaking problems that you may encounter. Fortunately you can save at any time... I would definitely suggest it.  It has been a while since there has been a game in this genre as good as this one. If you are a CRPG fan you MUST play this. If you are casual fan, get it on sale and try it out. Prepare to get sucked in for several months.

This is easily one of the best games I have ever played. Let's go over pro's and cons  1. Co-op. As a man that searches for games to play with his wife I love this idea. Couch co-op or online it is great. It's seemless going from sharing the same screen splitscreen gameplay between you and another co-op player. I love playing an RPG with my life and she loved it to. It also makes it easy to share dialogue options with two players and to quest together. We had so much fun together. 2. Visually beautiful. This game has a wonderfully colorful pallette. 3. Amount of gameplay time. The amount of content makes this game easily worth $100 and yet it goes for something like $40. A great value. 4. Storyline- Wow. Just wow. A multi- layered story with many stories interweaving in one another. Fantastic. I loved the stories. 5. Voice Acting and Music- Beautiful music and great voice overs. 6. Combat- fun turn based combat that uses the elements well. 7. Beautiful and varied enviroments. 8. Great controller support  Cons 1. The monster designs wtih a few exceptions (Bracchus Rex, Trife, the undeead mini bosses), were uninspired trope fantasy stock. 2. Puzzles- Some of them I just hated. I had to actually find a stupid switch I missed and I spent a long time looking for it! ugh! 3. Broken quest system- It's easy to miss a switch, accidently drop or lose an item, etc. Be careful not to sell or drop an item, key, or book unless you know for sure you don't need it or you can be screwed.  4. The Mapping system makes orienting and finding your position difficult for the direction challenged such as myself. There is no waypoint systems and the way the map moves makes finding east, west, north, south tricky. It could have been done better. They should have maintained it orienting north.  All that said. This game is so much fun, and playing hours upon hours with my wife was a great experience we both loved. I waited for the steam sale, but when they release a sequel we don't plan on waiting this time!
The Enhanced Edition of Divinity: Original Sin makes an amazing game more amazing.

Fantastic game! A great throwback to old school RPG pc. This Game does NOT hold your hand... You need to read everything incase you miss something important, and check all the corners. I lost count of how many times i was well and truly stumped at what to do next.. Until i spoke to a damn rat that gave me a clue or something like that. It reminded me of being a kid again really enjoying games because of this reason (thankfully we have the internet for help now when desperate).  The gameplay is fun, you have so many ways to go about doing anything that even the most simple of solutions seem sometimes way too obvious to do.   Slow turnbased combat isn't for everyone, So if you don't like it don't bother getting this game. Every single person/creature is brilliantly voice acted too, it really draws you in and is very addicting... Only downside is i wish there was a way to cause a delay on the background chatter.. It's nonstop repetition with no wait time (Highly annoying!)

After throwing 130+ hours in the Classic edition, i thought i'd 'speedrun' the Enhanced edition just for the achievements. Well, i ended up spending another 56 hours with this masterpiece. Not exactly a speedrun! Oh, and when Larian says 'enhanced', they mean it.  10/10

'ridiculous amount of content' - this is simply the best rpg out there on so many ways. The little stories for nearly every NPCs, every follower, your charakter - even enemies and animals. A completely free skill system, nice crafting and character development makes it pretty much more overwhelming.  You like Neverwinter Night's and Baldur's Gate? Then you will love this one!

I wanted to buy this game earlier, but decided to wait because I was intrigued by the Enhanced Edition and all the overhauling they have done. This game is not really a regular enhanced edition or remaster, it is a massively overhauled version of the award-winning 2014 RPG and Gamespot's PC Game of the Year 2014. What I loved about this is the fact that it's a publicly funded game by an indie dev, which means that it literally has no limits in terms of content. No crappy publisher-restrictions are there to hold them back like EA, Ubisoft or other Triple A devs/publishers. This reminds me of what CD Projekt did. Keep it up guys, looking forward to DOS 2.

Enhanced Edition as a title fails for what Larian did this to game. These aren't just new textures, or models. It plays like a whole new game. I think that Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition should be an example of how other RPG games should work. If you are looking for a fun co-op game to play online, or in your living room look no further. Co-op gameplay is seamless and fun. They have really built co-op into the story mechanics, as much as they have the gameplay. If you are looking for a long game, this is supposedly 100 hours of content. I don't believe that, because I've spent almost 50 hours and I am not even halfway. (No, I haven't been dying constantly.) Between the sidequests, puzzles, combat, the main story, and the crafting you will spend well over 100 hours on this game. I commend Larian studios for their incredible attention to detail, and their love for the game is shown in the work they put into it. Looking forward to Divinity 2.

Great combat and character systems, bright and colourful world, and fantastically designed co-op mechanics make this the perfect game to the play with a friend. The one area where it falls down is pacing; walking around Cyseal and going through 5000 dialogues one after another isn't my idea of a good time. Other than that, though, amazing game.

This game did so many things that were amazing.   1. It provided content on top of content. It seems crazy to expect so very much from a game without it requiring tons of DLC. To say I got the full value of what I paid is an understatement.   2. I am a big fan of RPG's and DnD. This game seemed to marry the two so well. That is a hard mark to hit.  3. It was so fun and SO HARD! I played on normal difficulty and while most of the time it was fine, but if you didn't stay vigilante you would die. It didn't hold your hand...which flirted with a bit obtuse sometimes but most of the time it was perfect.   4. The X factor of a well made game that you just want to keep coming back to.   All in all, the game had a few minor issues. But they seem to inconsequatial to mention. The story was good, perhaps a bit too stretched out in 100 hours of game play to be totally compelled by it. But it was still quite good.   Wow such a good game. If you don't mind putting a slower than average game than this one is for you. Remember that doesn't mean boring. Its just takes its time and has good pacing.

Awesome game with a great number of tactical choices, using the environment and mixing right elements to aid you in battle. The two new difficulty settings seems like a great addition, going through tactician mode now. Enemies actually seems to work more with logic, using things better to their advantage.  There is some puzzles here and there also, some of them not so straightforward and requires some thinking. Dialogues are all spoken, even the animals.  Crafting is also quite good, with it you can experiment different combinations and might just craft someting nice. Skillbooks and scrolls are also craftable if you find them blank. There are also recipes that you learn from books.  If you like turnbased combat, saving throws, rpg's then this game is absolutely worth looking into.

This game takes the old-school CRPG system and just does it right. Complete freedom to customize your characters, not restrained to specific classes. Any character can learn any skill, so you can create hybrid classes just the way you want them. Conversation and interaction play a huge role, so it's worthwhile to pay some attention to personality skills too. Combat is much more similar to the original Fallout games - turn-based tactical, although it's not restrained to a grid. Flanking, backstab bonuses, line of sight (including whether you have an ally between your archer and your target), and lots more make combat deep and rewarding.  And don't forget about the element interactions - environment and spell effects interact to a major degree. Enemies standing in a puddle of oil are much more vulnerable to burn damage. Throw a water balloon at an enemy to wet them, and follow up with a lightning attack for bonus damage. Toss a poison gas grenade at a group of enemies and then hit the volatile gas cloud with a fire arrow for some major explosion damage. Tons of interactive environmental things - room decorations like crates, barrels, chairs, etc. can be moved and aren't just decoration - in fact, moving these things is sometimes key to solving puzzles or progressing.  Even more mundane things like equipment repair, rare object identification, crafting, and all of that are handled very well.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who was a fan of games like Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment, or the old-school Fallout games.

[Review for the Enhanced Edition]  My wife and I played co-op on the original for 100 or so hours. I played the original solo with dual lone-wolf/glass cannon combo by myself for another hundred or so hours. I did not realize there was an enhanced edition let alone added to my library for free by owning the original until a couple weeks ago. Kudos to the devs for making that happen.  The enhanced edition makes some fundamemtal changes to the story arc, streamlining things and making it all seem more fluent. Story-wise, it makes more sense and flows better. Many gameplay changes also take place in this enhanced edition, and there are some good and bad points to that.  There are fewer 'line-of-sight' issues with the integrity of the game system to incorporate real-world effects with environmental interaction. Not as 'Omg, not again,' moments as in the original. Environmental effects, which is part of what makes this game so great, are not as devestatingly annoying.  On the other hand, as others have said, the 'line of sight' issues such as uphill battles and 'firing from your knees' is a concern. You can work with it, but you have to really understand the combat 'pixel point' system to really get a good feeling from it. Frustrating to mis-click and your character 'moves' to a new location instead of casting that ice bolt, or whatever, but if you understand and respect the beauty of the pixel-point environment then it makes sense and is cool. 'I can land a fireball on that troll's nose because it's JUST poking out from behind that boulder,' becomes a thing of glory instead of a frustration.  Inventory system is still somewhat cumbersome - getting things back and forth between characters but otherwise the whole system is brilliant and efficient. Vendors are no longer starved for gold, and the skill books are there aplenty instead of hoping that in a single playthrough you miss something. The changes to the skill system (adept, master, etc.) while limiting you to choose but while basically giving you every option to define your abilities is a welcome change. I.e., 'I can have mass-heal, once per combat, or hail attack as often as I want if I have the action points for it,' makes for an innovative strategy choice.  The balancing is a new feature and one that I appreciate. No more 'Lone wolf/Glass Cannon,' combinations. You can have one or the other. Many people I see complaining about this, but I for one welcome it. The difficulty is still weak enough that even without that powerhouse combo you can still feel like a god, but there is enough challenge that you have to pay attention even on the harder difficulties. If anything, the overall challenge is weak if you know the game, its effects, and combat environment effects because you can take advantage of everything -- but in games like this combat is generally the weak point.  Story-wise? Amusing, amazing, and, while not original (is anything possibly original anymore?) is fitting. The additions and editing of the Enhanced Edition streamline things in a way that has made playing through it again feel like a whole new game. Even my wife, who generally only plays games once, is planning on playing this again just based on the laughter she heard from me whilst playing as a result of the full voice-overs.  To owners of the original game, play it again with this edition. To those that haven't played it at all, give it a shot. For the price, it's hard to beat the entertainment dollar and even if you're a newb to classic RPG's you will laugh a few times while dying or finding new ways to steal a painting off the wall. Excellent addition to the genre and the full voice-overs, very well acted, just make it that much better. They even got rid of the screeching annoying voice-overs that drove many of us to tears (Cyseal Market, for those that don't know....)

In this day of DLC-happy games, (unfinished in my eyes), it's refreshing to see a game so complete, the details so well thoughtout. This game is made and executed the way games like the Baldur's Gate series and the Elder Scrolls series are with an open world, a solid storyline and plenty of side quests to complete along the way. I'm playing the single-player game in Adventuring mode which is the easiest one. Some pluses I especially like:  1. My two main characters affect each other through the choices they make which add or subtract to their abilities and to those of the rest of their team. 2. Rift travel. These are portals that are activated when approached. Once activated you can step into any portal and travel to any other you've activated. (There are more features but it would borderline on a spoiler to talk about it.) 3. Teleportation: You acquire 2 teleporter pyramids through a quest. They are linked to each other. You drop one somewhere you would like to return to, go on about your business, click on the pyramid in your pack and your team is transported back to the one you dropped.  4. Lots and lots, and lots, and lots, and lots of armor, weapons and items to choose from. 5. A great crafting/recipe system that allows you to make useful things without the grinding! You discover the Recipes by placing items in the slots on your Experiment page or acquire a recipe book that teaches it to you when you read the book. (The crafting system includes cooking, blacksmithing, potion-making, tailoring and spell-making and others, all on one character).  6. Dynamic and well-thoughtout dialogue. (example: My main character had purchased very expensive armor for her fighter. After he put it on he commented how expensive it was and thanked her for it.) It's little details like that that let you know how much the developers loved what they were making. 7. You are not tied to the skill-set you chose for your character at character creation. (example: My Wayfarer has her archery skills but now also has the ability to use wands and staves, as well as decent rogue skills.) 8. Lots of companions to chose from to complete your 4-person team anyway you like, (single-player). Some you can 'rent', (one-time fee), others you meet along the way and invite them to join. You can tell a team member to take a hike so you can switch him out for someone else and then put him back on the team when you need him again. He is sent to a warm and fuzzy 'rest area' with the other 'Island of Misfit Toys' you've temporarily retired. You can adventure alone or with 2, 3 or 4 companions.  9. Using tools for crafting, mining, repairing, cooking and others weigh very little and, no matter how big, take up only one block each in your inventory. As well, all other items, armor and weapons take up only one block. A backpack is included in your inventory to give you even more space.  10. Inventor: It's easy to switch between characters.  11. For all new players there is a cave/dungeon you are given a choice to enter to before you reach the first town. It's a very clever and useful way to introduce you to the dynamics of the game and some of the trickier traps you will come across later on. Obvious things like water-beats-fire but it shows you a possible way to do it you may not have thought of, (Like one area where I was instructed to drag a candle over to a pool of oil under some skels to set the oil and the skels on fire). In other words...use your environment, look around you, there are different ways to accomplish the same task.  Minus: 1. I can't play this game 24-7...I've tried. But my husband and my two dogs keep bugging me to be fed and paid attention to. Isn't that what tv dinners and canned dog food are made for?...geesh!

This game is mostly great and if you enjoy a good RPG with interesting turn based combat, then you should give this game a try. For me, the combat was the highlight of the game as the classes and related abilities make each battle unique. Furthermore, the synergies between spells, abilities, and environmental elements make combat highly unpredictable, constantly keeping you on your toes. That being said, this game has some flaws that I need to mention so that potential buyers aren't caught unaware. If you can look past these flaws, then you'll enjoy this game.  First and foremost are the bugs. I find myself constantly annoyed by something that doesn't work right. Whether it's a crafting recipe, a combination of spells interacting erratically or not at all, or some random effect that happens inexplicably (i.e. dealing poison damage by shooting a silver arrow). The turn order indicator at the top of the screen will sometimes get stuck and you'll have no idea whose turn it is.   Knowing the type of surface you're standing on is extremely important, however, many times I found that the surface texture wasn't showing correctly so I end up standing in an electrified puddle, or poison, or fire, when there's nothing showing under my character. What makes this even more problematic is that your characters will happily run right into these hazards instead of pathing around them. There are further annoyances, however these are a few examples of what to expect. I've also had some crashes on rare occasions but it's mostly the in game bugs that are the most problematic. The key is to save often. Thankfully the game lets you save at almost any time, even during combat.  The reason that the above issues are more than minor nuisances is that the game can be very hard. There's nothing wrong with a difficult game, but when you have to constantly contend with the problems mentioned above, it takes away from the fun and makes the experience more aggravating.   Finally, the difficulty curve is all over the place. One moment you'll be ripping through a group of enemies with ease, and the next you get destroyed before you've had your first turn. It just feels completely random. This appears to be done purposefully as there are some events\encounters that just outright kill you, and you have to reload, so prepare to quicksave\quickload often.

I'm a bit conflicted about the game. Overall, I enjoyed the combat system and the difficulty. It's refreshing to play a game that doesn't nerf everything to avoid player frustration. This game definitely makes you 'get good' otherwise you get dead. Save early and save often. Pros: Combat is fun in Divinity. The elemental magic system was cool and I like that if you mix elements (like electricity and water or poison and fire) there's a reaction. The abilities and character creation are simple, but they work well within the game. The graphics, specifically the effects and the glossy nature of the images, are on point. The soundtrack fits the game well. Cons: The story didn't pull me in at all. I did like the idea of time and how it the characters worked within that, but otherwise it just didn't interest me. Group members will actively run into lava or traps, even when there is a simple route around, that set them on fire or blow them up with pie-eyed glee (killing an entire party). UI is super clunky and involves a lot of tedious dragging and clicking (with the exception of the recipe crafting). Several character attributes (like blacksmithing) are mostly pointless. Technically they have a purpose, but they are really just a waste. By the time you get good enough to craft a decent blade, bow, etc. you can find something much, much better. Actually, due to the linear nature of the game you WILL find weapons much better than anything you can make. The only reason crafting is useful is to make arrows or potions. Potions alone will save a ton of money. Dinners are helpful in a pinch too. Beyond that, I found the skill to be pointless. Same went for lockpicking (just set the safes and doors on fire). Trying to talk to animals was fun, but chasing rats was a pain.  All in all it's a fun game, with some novel mechanics, but I have no real desire to finish it. So, if you are itching for a group-style RPG ala Baldur's Gate (sans epic story), then this is a decent game.
